<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 195, 220, 207]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 195, 907, 207]]<|/det|>
9709/12

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 217, 907, 231]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 (P1) **October/November 2012**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 239, 907, 252]]<|/det|>
**1 hour 45 minutes**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 260, 460, 274]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 273, 390, 286]]<|/det|>
Graph Paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 287, 463, 301]]<|/det|>
List of Formulae (MF9)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 323, 390, 336]]<|/det|>
# READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 828, 366]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 368, 722, 382]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 327, 398]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 497, 415]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 601, 431]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 285, 461]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 463, 907, 492]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 589, 508]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 606, 524]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 540, 606, 554]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 556, 756, 570]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 440, 586]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 907, 617]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 865, 660, 879]]<|/det|>
This document consists of 4 printed pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 855, 102]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \(\left(x^{2} - \frac{a}{x}\right)^{7}\), the coefficient of \(x^{5}\) is \(-280\). Find the value of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 77, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 138, 97, 156]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 623, 168]]<|/det|>
A function f is such that \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \sqrt{\left(\frac{x + 3}{2}\right) + 1},\) for \(x \geqslant - 3\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 172, 154, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 170, 660, 192]]<|/det|>
f \(^{- 1}(x)\) in the form \(a x^{2} + b x + c\) , where \(a\) , \(b\) and \(c\) are constants,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 197, 154, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 306, 216]]<|/det|>
the domain of \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 199, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 243, 97, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 255, 700, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 440, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a plan for a rectangular park \(ABCD\), in which \(AB = 40 \text{m}\) and \(AD = 60 \text{m}\). Points \(X\) and \(Y\) lie on \(BC\) and \(CD\) respectively and \(AX\), \(XY\) and \(YA\) are paths that surround a triangular playground. The length of \(DY\) is \(x \text{m}\) and the length of \(XC\) is \(2x \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 504, 154, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 601, 523]]<|/det|>
Show that the area, \(A \mathrm{~m}^{2}\), of the playground is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 529, 583, 549]]<|/det|>
\[A = x^{2} - 30x + 1200.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 567, 153, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 567, 670, 587]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x\) can vary, find the minimum area of the playground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 616, 94, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 868, 641]]<|/det|>
The line \(y = \frac{x}{k} + k\), where \(k\) is a constant, is a tangent to the curve \(4y = x^2\) at the point \(P\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 647, 153, 665]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 647, 275, 666]]<|/det|>
the value of \(k\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 672, 139, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 672, 326, 691]]<|/det|>
the coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 672, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 82, 700, 292]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 311, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a triangle \(ABC\) in which \(A\) has coordinates (1, 3), \(B\) has coordinates (5, 11) and angle \(ABC\) is \(90^{\circ}\). The point \(X\) (4, 4) lies on \(AC\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 352, 151, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 352, 319, 371]]<|/det|>
the equation of \(BC\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 352, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 377, 151, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 377, 329, 395]]<|/det|>
the coordinates of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 377, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 422, 96, 441]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 422, 843, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label> Show that the equation \(2\cos x = 3\tan x\) can be written as a quadratic equation in \(\sin x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 422, 920, 441]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 454, 153, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 454, 606, 473]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(2\cos 2y = 3\tan 2y\), for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant y \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 454, 920, 473]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 500, 96, 520]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 751, 520]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of the points \(A\) and \(B\), relative to an origin \(O\), are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 526, 640, 574]]<|/det|>
\[\overrightarrow{OA} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \overrightarrow{OB} = \begin{pmatrix} k \\ -k \\ 2k \end{pmatrix},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 580, 292, 599]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 611, 156, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 611, 524, 630]]<|/det|>
In the case where \(k = 2\), calculate angle \(AOB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 644, 153, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 644, 556, 663]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(k\) for which \(\overrightarrow{AB}\) is a unit vector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 691, 96, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 146, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 691, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
In a geometric progression, all the terms are positive, the second term is 24 and the fourth term is \(13\frac{1}{2}\). Find

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 734, 196, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 734, 307, 752]]<|/det|>
the first term,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 734, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 758, 191, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 758, 499, 777]]<|/det|>
the sum to infinity of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 758, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 790, 146, 808]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 790, 920, 824]]<|/det|>
A circle is divided into \(n\) sectors in such a way that the angles of the sectors are in arithmetic progression. The smallest two angles are \(3^{\circ}\) and \(5^{\circ}\). Find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 806, 920, 824]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 268, 920, 318]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{9}{2x + 3}\), crossing the \(y\)-axis at the point \(B(0, 3)\). The point \(A\) on the curve has coordinates (3, 1) and the tangent to the curve at \(A\) crosses the \(y\)-axis at \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 327, 556, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label> Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 327, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 771, 375]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 374]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 920, 418]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 866, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 806, 920, 842]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(20\mathrm{cm}\). A circle with centre \(C\) and radius \(x\mathrm{cm}\) lies within the sector and touches it at \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\). Angle \(PQR = 1.2\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 852, 153, 870]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 851, 549, 870]]<|/det|>
